title: Remedial English: Let's Practice!
description: Hier kun je Engelse grammatica oefenen op het niveau wat jouw docent heeft aangegeven. Veel succes!

items.content:
Welcome to this online learning environment where you can practice English grammar! Here you can find different levels to practice with. To figure out your level, you may start with the 'nulmeting' listed below.

Nulmeting (B1)

If you have a score of 80% or higher (12 points or more) on B1, you are encouraged to also try out the B2 version:

Nulmeting (B2)

You can choose from the following levels:

A2 (beginner)

B1 (intermediate)

B2 (upper-intermediate)

C1 (advanced)

The goal of this arrangement is to offer you, the student, an extra space to practice your grammar. Since we don't offer much grammar during class, but quite a few of you have told us you'd like to practice your grammar skills, your English teachers thought an online environment would be a great place to do so.

This website will help you prepare for your exams, and if you're at mbo, it will also help you create your language portfolio.

You can use this website at home, or during class when you're done with your assigned work. You can use this website at your own pace. It will be expanded still, so if you're done with everything, there will be more added soon.
In this menu you'll find all grammar assignments on A2 - Beginner level. If your teacher has indicated you're at A2 level, this is where you should start!

Positive:

I am I'm

He

She

It

 is

He's

She's

It's

We

You

They

 are

we're

you're

they're

Negative:

I am not I'm not

He

She

It

 is not

he's not / he isn't

she's not / she's isn't

it's not / it isn't

We

You

They

 are not

we're not / we aren't

you're not / you aren't

they're not / they aren't

In the columns above you can see the longer forms (first two columns) and short forms (third column). You may use this to help with the exercises.

These short forms are examples of everyday speech you can use with your friends and family. In a more formal setting, you'll use the longer form.

<iframe src="https://h5p.iminor.nl/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php?action=h5p_embed&id=5552" width="960" height="1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen" title="Complete the sentences using the short form."/>
 <iframe src="https://h5p.iminor.nl/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php?action=h5p_embed&id=5551" width="960" height="1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen" title="Choose am, is or are."/>
 <iframe src="https://h5p.iminor.nl/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php?action=h5p_embed&id=5550" width="960" height="1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen" title="Short forms"/>

I am I'm

He

She

It

 is

He's

She's

It's

We

You

They

 are

we're

you're

they're

This you already know from the previous set of assignments. To make a question, you'll simply switch it around:

am I?
is

he?

she?

it?
are

we?

they?

you?

Present simple

You use the present simple for things that are true in general, or happen sometimes or all the time.

For example:

I like big cities

You speak English very well

Tim works very hard

<iframe src="https://h5p.iminor.nl/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php?action=h5p_embed&id=5558" width="960" height="1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen" title="Write these words with -s or -es"/>
 <iframe src="https://h5p.iminor.nl/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php?action=h5p_embed&id=5559" width="960" height="1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen" title="Complete the sentences"/>
 <iframe src="https://h5p.iminor.nl/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php?action=h5p_embed&id=5560" width="960" height="527" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen" title="Write sentences with the words"/>

These assignments will teach you about the 'present continious'. You use this when talking of something that is happening now.

am/is/are + doing/eating/running,

Some examples:

I am working

She's wearing a hat

They're playing football
<iframe src="https://h5p.iminor.nl/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php?action=h5p_embed&id=5556" width="960" height="1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen" title="Complete the sentences"/>

Present Simple negative.

The present simple negative is very similar to the present simple. You use this form to state things that are (generally) true, but instead of a positive thing, this is a negative thing. You turn a sentence negative by adding "not".

I work - I don't / do not work

We like - We don't / do not like

You do - You don't / do not

They have - They haven't / have not

He works - He doesn't / does not work

She likes - She doesn't / does not like

It has - It hasn't / has not

<iframe src="https://h5p.iminor.nl/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php?action=h5p_embed&id=5561" width="960" height="1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen" title="Write the negative"/>
 <iframe src="https://h5p.iminor.nl/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php?action=h5p_embed&id=5562" width="960" height="1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen" title="Complete the sentences"/>
 <iframe src="https://h5p.iminor.nl/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php?action=h5p_embed&id=5563" width="960" height="1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen" title="Put the verb into the correct form"/>
In this menu you'll find all grammar assignments on B1 - Intermediate level. If your teacher has indicated you're at B1 level, this is where you should start!

Have (got) is a form we use to as a third person singular. We talk about something we have, such as possession, relationships, illnesses and characteristics. When you say 'I have', it's informal. To sound more formal, you can add the word 'got'; "I have got a brother".

I

We

You

They

 have

He

She

It

 has

Or

I

We

You

They

 have got

I've got

we've got

you've got

they've got

He

She

It

 has got

He's got

She's got

It's got

You'll remember I have from previous lessons. I've got... is an addition to that. As you can see,we have a long and a short form here again.

Present perfect

We use this form to tell about something that has started in the past, and continues on in the present.

When you say "I have cleaned", it means you cleaned in the past, but the cleanliness is still visible now.

has cleaned / have gone, and so on is called the 'present perfect'. (have + past participle).

Some examples of the past participle are:

cleaned - finished - started - lost - done - been - gone.
<iframe src="https://h5p.iminor.nl/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php?action=h5p_embed&id=5567" width="960" height="1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen" title="Complete the sentences"/>

heading.content: I've just / I've already / I haven't yet (present perfect 2)

items.content:
I've just...

Just = a short time ago.

"I've just arrived"

I've already....

already = before it was expected

"I've already finished"

I haven't.... yet. / Have you.... yet?

yet = until now. We use yet in negative sentences, and it's usually at the end.

"I haven't done that yet"

"Have you finished your homework yet?"

We often use just, yet, still and already with the present perfect because they are related to the present moment.
<iframe src="https://h5p.iminor.nl/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php?action=h5p_embed&id=5569" width="960" height="1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen" title="Complete the sentences"/>

We use the present perfect (have been, have had, have played, etc) when we talk about a time from the past until now. It is often used to talk about things you have done in your life, without saying when you did them. For example, a person's life:

"Have you ever been to Japan?"

"I have been on TV"

"I have never played golf."

"My sister has never travelled on a plane."

By using 'how long have you..." you ask someone for how long they have been doing something. For instance:

"How long have you been working there?" "Since 1992"

"For how long have you been in Ireland?" "I have been here for three days"

<iframe src="https://h5p.iminor.nl/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php?action=h5p_embed&id=5572" width="960" height="401" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen" title="Complete the sentences"/>
 <iframe src="https://h5p.iminor.nl/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php?action=h5p_embed&id=5573" width="960" height="439" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen" title="Make questions"/>
In this menu you'll find all grammar assignments on B2 - Upper-intermediate level. If your teacher has indicated you're at B2 level, this is where you should start!

Present perfect

We use this form to tell about something that has started in the past, and continues on in the present.

When you say "I have cleaned", it means you cleaned in the past, but the cleanliness is still visible now.

The present perfect simple is have/has + past participle.

Some examples of the past participle are:

cleaned - finished - started - lost - done - been - gone.

<iframe src="https://h5p.iminor.nl/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php?action=h5p_embed&id=5574" width="960" height="1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen" title="Read the situations and complete the sentence using the present perfect."/>
 <iframe src="https://h5p.iminor.nl/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php?action=h5p_embed&id=5575" width="960" height="1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen" title="Complete the sentences"/>

heading.content: I have been doing (present perfect continuous)

items.content:
Remember the present continuous? Some examples of it are:

"I am working"

"It is raining"

Now, we're going to apply the 'perfect' tense to it.

have/has been +ing = present perfect continous.

"I have been working"

"It has been raining"

The present perfect continuous describes an action or situation that started in the past (usually in the recent past) and continues in the present. The actions are normally temporary situations. For example, He's been running since 3:30.

<iframe src="https://h5p.iminor.nl/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php?action=h5p_embed&id=5577" width="960" height="1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen" title="Write a question for each situation."/>
 <iframe src="https://h5p.iminor.nl/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php?action=h5p_embed&id=5578" width="960" height="1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen" title="Read the situations and complete the sentences."/>
 <iframe src="https://h5p.iminor.nl/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php?action=h5p_embed&id=5579" width="960" height="555" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen" title="Complete the sentences"/>
Below you'll find a video that explains the difference between the present perfect and the present continuous:

<iframe src="https://h5p.iminor.nl/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php?action=h5p_embed&id=5580" width="960" height="1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen" title="Complete the sentences"/>
 <iframe src="https://h5p.iminor.nl/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php?action=h5p_embed&id=5581" width="960" height="1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen" title="Complete the sentences"/>

We use 'for' and 'since' to say how long something has been happening.

"We have been waiting for two hours"

"I have been in Italy since last month"

You can use 'in' instead of 'for' in a negative sentence:

"I haven't been on holiday in ten years" (for ten years)
<iframe src="https://h5p.iminor.nl/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php?action=h5p_embed&id=5582" width="960" height="1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen" title="Choose for or since"/>

The past perfect (simple) is:

had + past participle (gone, finished, seen).

We use it to talk about something that has already happened in the past.

"When Sarah arrived at the party, Paul had already gone home"

The past perfect refers to a time earlier than before now. It is used to make it clear that one event happened before another in the past. It does not matter which event is mentioned first - the tense makes it clear which one happened first.

<iframe src="https://h5p.iminor.nl/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php?action=h5p_embed&id=5584" width="960" height="1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen" title="Complete the sentences"/>
 <iframe src="https://h5p.iminor.nl/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php?action=h5p_embed&id=5585" width="960" height="1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen" title="Complete the sentences"/>

We use "used to" to talk about something that you did once, but don't anymore.

"I used to take a run every day", which means that, at one point in the past, I ran every day,but I don't anymore.

<iframe src="https://h5p.iminor.nl/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php?action=h5p_embed&id=5586" width="960" height="1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen" title="Complete the sentences"/>
 <iframe src="https://h5p.iminor.nl/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php?action=h5p_embed&id=5587" width="960" height="1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen" title="Complete the sentences"/>
In this menu you'll find all grammar assignments on C1 - Advanced level. If your teacher has indicated you're at C1 level, this is where you should start!

heading.content: I had been doing (past perfect continuous)

items.content:
The past perfect continuous is used when something has been going on in the past. For instance:

It had been raining.

It was not raining when I looked out the window, the sun was shining. But it had been raining before.
<iframe src="https://h5p.iminor.nl/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php?action=h5p_embed&id=5589" width="960" height="1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen" title="Complete the sentences"/>

We use 'will' when we've just decided to do something. When we say "I'll do something" we announce our decision.

"Oh, I left the door open. I'll go and shut it."

We use 'shall' mostly in questions.

"Shall I open the window?"

<iframe src="https://h5p.iminor.nl/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php?action=h5p_embed&id=5590" width="960" height="1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen" title="Fill in the blankes"/>
 <iframe src="https://h5p.iminor.nl/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php?action=h5p_embed&id=5591" width="960" height="1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen" title="Complete the sentences"/>

heading.content: I will and I'm going to

items.content:
We use both 'will' and 'going to' for future happenings and situations.

For instance:

"I think the weather will be nicer tomorrow"

"I'm going to get some groceries later today"

<iframe src="https://h5p.iminor.nl/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php?action=h5p_embed&id=5592" width="960" height="1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen" title="Complete the sentences"/>
 <iframe src="https://h5p.iminor.nl/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php?action=h5p_embed&id=5593" width="960" height="1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen" title="Complete the sentences"/>

heading.content: Will be doing and will have done

items.content:
We use 'will be doing' to tell someone we'll be in the middle of something.

"I will be doing that exam, so don't text me that day"

"Don't phone between 7 and 8, we'll be eating"

We use "I will have done" to tell someone what we're doing will be done before a certain time in the future.

"I will have finished before dinner"

"She'll be arriving home before movie night"

<iframe src="https://h5p.iminor.nl/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php?action=h5p_embed&id=5594" width="960" height="1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen" title="Complete the sentences"/>
 <iframe src="https://h5p.iminor.nl/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php?action=h5p_embed&id=5596" width="960" height="1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen" title="Complete the sentences"/>

We use 'may' or 'might' to say that something is possible.

"It may be true" or "it might be true" (perhaps it is true!)

"She might know" or "She may know" (perhaps she knows).

The negative forms are "may not" and "might not". You apply these the same way as you would the positive form.

<iframe src="https://h5p.iminor.nl/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php?action=h5p_embed&id=5597" width="960" height="1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen" title="Complete the sentences"/>
 <iframe src="https://h5p.iminor.nl/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php?action=h5p_embed&id=5598" width="960" height="1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen" title="Complete the sentences"/>
On this page, you can find a bunch of grammar games to take your practice even further!

Grammar Games Online

ESL Games World

Grammar Gorillas

On each of these websites you'll find many games to help you practice your grammar! There's a lot of them, so there should definitely be something there you'll like.
Below you can find some videos in which Lucy explains some grammar.

Daalen, K., Ijzerman, M. (2014) Can Do Engels: MBO Breed. Amersfoort: Deviant.

Murphy, R. (2011) Essential Grammar in Use. Cambridge University Press.

Murphy, R. (2019) English Grammar in Use. Cambridge University Press.

Noordhoff (z.d.) NU Engels (2e ed) Groningen: Noordhoff.
